taxonConcepts.nameAccordingTo: Species 2000 & ITIS Catalogue of Life: April 2013

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObjects.title: Biology
dataObjects.description: Inhabits clear, swift streams with sandy bottom (Ref. 41236). Also collected from slow-flowing streams and oxbows (Ref. 83671).

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObjects.title: Range Description
dataObjects.rights: © International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources
dataObjects.rightsHolder: International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources
dataObjects.bibliographicCitation: Dahanukar, N. 2010. Lepidocephalichthys annandalei. In: IUCN 2014 . IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2014.1 . <www.iucnredlist.org>
dataObjects.description: Lepidocephalichthys annandalei is known from West Bengal (Mahananda River, Tista River, Darjeeling); Meghalaya (Garo Hills); and Uttar Pradesh (Dehra Dun, Nainital); Bihar; Uttarankhand; and Uttar Pradesh (Menon 1992). The species is likely to be present in Nepal, and is reported in Bangladesh (Havird and Page 2010).

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObjects.description: Asia:  India (Assam), Bangladesh, and Nepal in the Ganges and Brahmaputradrainages.
dataObjects.references: Havird, J.C. and L.M. Page 2010 A revision of Lepidocephalichthys (Teleostei: Cobitidae) with descriptions of two new species from Thailand, Laos, Vietnam, and Myanmar. Copeia 2010(1):137-159. (Ref. 83671)

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Size
dataObjects.title: Max. size
dataObjects.references: Havird, J.C. and L.M. Page 2010 A revision of Lepidocephalichthys (Teleostei: Cobitidae) with descriptions of two new species from Thailand, Laos, Vietnam, and Myanmar. Copeia 2010(1):137-159. (Ref. 83671)

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription
dataObjects.description: Distinguished from all congeners by its unique caudal fin coloration, consisting of two distinct black spots (one at upper base of fin and one at center of posterior edge of fin).  Further differs from all Lepidocephalichthys by the combination of the following characters:  caudal fin with two broad, dark V-shaped bands; truncated/notched caudal fin; scales on top of head absent or embedded; dorsal-fin origin anterior to pelvic-fin origin; moderate/large size up to 4.3 cm SL); small barbels, first rostral pair never reaching anterior nostril (Ref. 83671).

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Conservation

dataObjects.rights: © International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources

dataObjects.bibliographicCitation: Dahanukar, N. 2010. Lepidocephalichthys annandalei. In: IUCN 2014 . IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2014.1 . <www.iucnredlist.org>
dataObjects.description:
Red List Category
LC
Least Concern

Red List Criteria

Version
3.1

Year Assessed
2010

Assessor/s
Dahanukar, N.

Reviewer/s
Rema Devi, K.R., Arunachalam, M., Dahanukar, N., Allen, D.J., Daniel, B.A. & Molur, S.

Contributor/s
Molur, S.

Justification
Lepidocephalichthys annandalei is distributed throughout the hill streams of the Ganges and Brahmaputra basins, with no major threats and is assessed as Least Concern.
